philjs-router

View source

File-based routing with nested routes, data loading, and navigation.

Functions

Root router component that enables routing in your application.

function Router(props: RouterProps): JSX.Element

Parameters

props.url?stringInitial URL (for SSR)
props.base?stringBase path for all routes
props.childrenJSX.ElementRoute components

Example

1import { Router, Route } from 'philjs-router';
2 
3function App() {
4  return (
5    <Router>
6      <Route path="/" component={Home} />
7      <Route path="/about" component={About} />
8      <Route path="/users/:id" component={UserProfile} />
9    </Router>
10  );
11}

Defines a route that renders a component when the path matches.

function Route(props: RouteProps): JSX.Element

Parameters

props.pathstringURL path pattern to match
props.component?ComponentComponent to render when matched
props.children?JSX.ElementNested routes
props.data?(args) => Promise<T>Data loader function

Example

1// Basic route
2<Route path="/about" component={About} />
3 
4// With parameters
5<Route path="/users/:id" component={UserProfile} />
6 
7// With data loading
8<Route
9  path="/posts/:id"
10  component={PostPage}
11  data={({ params }) => fetchPost(params.id)}
12/>
13 
14// Nested routes
15<Route path="/dashboard" component={Dashboard}>
16  <Route path="/settings" component={Settings} />
17  <Route path="/profile" component={Profile} />
18</Route>

Returns a function to programmatically navigate between routes.

function useNavigate(): (path: string, options?: NavigateOptions) => void

Returns

(path: string, options?: NavigateOptions) => voidNavigation function

Example

1function LoginButton() {
2  const navigate = useNavigate();
3 
4  const handleLogin = async () => {
5    await login();
6    navigate('/dashboard');
7  };
8 
9  return <button onClick={handleLogin}>Login</button>;
10}
11 
12// With options
13navigate('/profile', { replace: true });
14navigate('/search', { state: { query: 'philjs' } });

Returns the current route parameters.

function useParams<T extends Params>(): T

Returns

TObject containing route parameters

Example

1// Route: /users/:id/posts/:postId
2function PostPage() {
3  const params = useParams<{ id: string; postId: string }>();
4 
5  return (
6    <div>
7      User ID: {params.id}
8      Post ID: {params.postId}
9    </div>
10  );
11}

Returns the current location object.

function useLocation(): Location

Returns

LocationCurrent location with pathname, search, hash, etc.

Example

1function CurrentPath() {
2  const location = useLocation();
3 
4  return (
5    <div>
6      <p>Pathname: {location.pathname}</p>
7      <p>Search: {location.search}</p>
8      <p>Hash: {location.hash}</p>
9    </div>
10  );
11}

Returns the current search params and a function to update them.

function useSearchParams(): [URLSearchParams, (params: Params) => void]

Returns

[URLSearchParams, (params: Params) => void]Search params and setter function

Example

1function SearchPage() {
2  const [searchParams, setSearchParams] = useSearchParams();
3 
4  const query = searchParams.get('q') || '';
5  const page = parseInt(searchParams.get('page') || '1');
6 
7  const updateSearch = (newQuery: string) => {
8    setSearchParams({ q: newQuery, page: '1' });
9  };
10 
11  return (
12    <div>
13      <input
14        value={query}
15        onInput={(e) => updateSearch(e.currentTarget.value)}
16      />
17      <p>Page: {page}</p>
18    </div>
19  );
20}

Returns the data loaded by the route's data function.

function useRouteData<T>(): T | undefined

Returns

T | undefinedData returned from the route data loader

Example

1<Route
2  path="/posts/:id"
3  component={PostPage}
4  data={async ({ params }) => {
5    const res = await fetch(`/api/posts/${params.id}`);
6    return res.json();
7  }}
8/>
9 
10function PostPage() {
11  const post = useRouteData<Post>();
12 
13  return (
14    <Show when={post}>
15      {(postData) => (
16        <article>
17          <h1>{postData.title}</h1>
18          <p>{postData.content}</p>
19        </article>
20      )}
21    </Show>
22  );
23}

Navigation link component with client-side routing.

function Link(props: LinkProps): JSX.Element

Parameters

props.hrefstringURL to navigate to
props.replace?booleanReplace history instead of push
props.state?anyState to pass to the next route
props.activeClass?stringClass to add when link is active

Example

1<Link href="/about">About Us</Link>
2 
3<Link href="/dashboard" replace>
4  Go to Dashboard
5</Link>
6 
7<Link
8  href="/search"
9  state={{ query: 'philjs' }}
10  activeClass="active"
11>
12  Search
13</Link>

Component that navigates when rendered.

function Navigate(props: NavigateProps): null

Parameters

props.hrefstringURL to navigate to
props.replace?booleanReplace history instead of push

Example

1function ProtectedRoute() {
2  const user = useUser();
3 
4  return (
5    <Show
6      when={user()}
7      fallback={<Navigate href="/login" />}
8    >
9      <Dashboard />
10    </Show>
11  );
12}

Types

Represents the current browser location.

Properties

PropertyTypeDescription
pathnamestringThe path portion of the URL
searchstringThe query string
hashstringThe hash fragment
stateanyLocation state
keystringUnique key for this location

Options for programmatic navigation.

Properties

PropertyTypeDescription
replace?booleanReplace current entry instead of adding new one
state?anyState to associate with the navigation
scroll?booleanWhether to scroll to top on navigation(default: true)

Arguments passed to route data functions.

Properties

PropertyTypeDescription
paramsParamsRoute parameters from the URL
locationLocationCurrent location object
dataanyData from parent routes
